questionListItems.title: Can S Pass or Work Permit holders be registered as company directors or secretaries? What are the consequences of doing so?

answer.body:
No, S Pass or Work Permit holders are not allowed to be shareholder, or to own or manage any business in Singapore. 

Therefore, they cannot register themselves as sole-proprietors, partners, directors or secretaries of any Singapore-registered company with the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (ACRA). 

If they do so, they will have infringed the Conditions of S Pass and Work Permit and their work passes will be revoked. They will also need to serve an employment ban.

S Pass or Work Permit holders who hold the job title of "Secretary" and are not registered with the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (ACRA) are not considered to be in violation of their work pass conditions.

questionListItems.title: Can the clinic charge an additional administrative fee for submitting the 6ME results?

answer.body: Yes, clinics can determine their own fee for the six-monthly medical examination (6ME), which may include any associated administrative work. Before sending your worker for the 6ME, you can contact the clinic to find out more about their costs.

questionListItems.title: I have just hired local employees and paid their CPF contributions. Can MOM update my quota manually as I urgently need to hire foreigners?

answer.body:
No, we are unable to amend your quota numbers manually. 

The foreign worker quota is updated automatically every Saturday based on the local CPF payments and declared salaries, which you can check on the next working day (i.e. Monday). 

Depending on when the CPF contributions were made, it may take around 2 Saturdays from the time we receive the CPF payment, for the average local workforce to be updated. 

We use 3-month average  of the local workforce when computing the foreign worker quota entitlement. You need to ensure that you have enough quota before you can hire additional foreign workers. 

For new organisations with no prior CPF contributions, the quota will be allocated based on the 1st-month local CPF contribution.

questionListItems.title: I have been asked to submit a verification proof in support of my work pass application, what are the requirements for it?

answer.body:
If you are applying for an Employment Pass (EP), please refer to the verification proof requirements for EP. 

Otherwise, please refer to the following if you have been asked to submit a verification proof for:

Employment recordShow

Your verification proof should confirm that your employment record is authentic.

Educational qualificationShow

Your verification proof should confirm the: 

  • Authenticity of the qualification
  • Accreditation status of the institution

Authenticity checks confirm that the candidate was awarded the qualification. Accreditation checks confirm the qualification is recognised by the local government authority.

Educational certificates certified by a notary public and school letters are not accepted as a form of verification proof.

questionListItems.title: What happens if i exceed my foreign worker quota?

answer.body:
Once you have exceeded your quota entitlement, your quota balance will be reflected as negative (i.e. below 0) on WP Online. Your Work Permit  or S Pass applications or renewals may be rejected.

You may also need to cancel the excessWork Permit or S Passes to meet the quota. If you fail do this in time, your excess work passes will be revoked and your company will not be allowed to hire new foreign workers for 6 months.

questionListItems.title: Why does WP Online show that i have less locals than the number of employees i have contributed CPF to for the past 3 months?

answer.body:
Here are the possible reasons: 

  • Your company has local employees who are receiving CPF contributions from 3 or more companies.  Such local employees are not counted towards the local workforce.  You can check with your local employees to find out who is receiving such multiple CPF contributions. MOM does not have the information.
  • You have late or backdated CPF contributions for your local employees. Such contributions may not be counted when computing the foreign worker quota, even if you pay off the arrears, late interests or fines due.
  • Your company has local employees with CPF contributions in multiple CPF accounts under your company (e.g. PTE-01, PTE-02 etc). For computing of local workforce and foreign worker quota, MOM will only count the same local employee once. 
  • Your CPF contributions were not in time for the foreign worker quota update that takes place every Saturday. Please check your local workforce count and foreign worker quota again on the next working day (i.e. Monday) after the following Saturday. 
  • You have local employees earning below $1,400 per month. A local employee earning below $700 per month is not counted in your company's local workforce. A local employee earning at least $700 to below $1,400 per month is counted as 0.5 local employee. 
  • Errors in CPF Submission: Any error in your CPF submission (e.g. wrongly declared your local employees’ salaries or the CPF contribution month) may affect your local workforce count and foreign worker quota calculation.

questionListItems.title: Can I still use the job advertisement to support an EP or S Pass application (to meet FCF requirements) if I cannot find the job title in the Self-Assessment Tool (SAT)?

answer.body:
If your job advertisement is still valid, you can still use it for submitting an EP or S Pass application even if the job title is no longer found in the Self-Assessment Tool (SAT).

MOM has updated the occupation list to include the latest job titles by referring to Department Of Statistics' Singapore Standard Occupational Classification (SSOC) 2020 edition.

questionListItems.title: What can I do if I am receiving a salary less than PWM wage requirements?

answer.body:
If you are covered under PWM, but paid less than the PWM wage requirements, you should approach your employer to seek clarification on your wage, occupation and hours of work.

If there are disagreements, email us at mom_lrwd@mom.gov.sg to report the matter.

questionListItems.title: When will the revised AE subscription and transaction fees be reflected?

answer.body:
The revised fees with 9% GST will be reflected in your fees incurred in January 2024.

You will receive your January 2024 AE fees in the following month of February 2024. The AE fees will be deducted through your current GIRO arrangement.

questionListItems.title: Why is there an increase now when we transit to 9% GST on 1 January 2024, when there was no increase when we transited to 8% GST on 1 January 2023?

answer.body:
There was a public announcement that Government fees and charges will not rise in 2023.

However, for the year 2024, you may notice a slight increase in your usual fees from your bill received from February 2024 onwards due to the increment of GST.

questionListItems.title: How are PMETs counted under the Diversity (C3) and Support for Local Employment (C4) criteria for COMPASS?

answer.body:
If your employees are They are counted as PMETs if they
 Foreign

Earn at least $3,000 in fixed monthly salary, as declared in their work pass application.

Note: The PMET count for foreign employees excludes: 

  • In-Principle Approvals (for all pass types)
  • Work Holiday Pass
  • Tech Pass
  • ONE Pass
  • Pre-Approved Letter of Consent.

 Local

(Singapore Citizens or Permanent Residents (PRs) your organisation contributes CPF for)

 Earn at least $3,000 per month, based on the CPF Ordinary and Additional wages declared for CPF contributions.

  • The fixed monthly salary of $3,000 is the same as the S Pass qualifying salary for renewals. The amount will be revised alongside future increases to the S Pass qualifying salary.
  • PRs are considered as foreigners based on their nationality under C3 (diversity) but are counted as locals under C4 (local PMET share).

questionListItems.title: How does COMPASS calculate my candidate’s nationality/citizenship share among my organisation’s PMETs?

answer.body:
The share of PMETs from a specific nationality/citizenship is calculated by taking the number of PMET employees from a specific nationality/citizenship and dividing it by the total number of PMET employees.

The nationality/citizenship of your organisation's employees, including Permanent Residents, is based on the nationality/citizenship on their passport in the Singapore Government’s records.

Example:

Using an example of an organisation with 100 PMET employees in total, this illustration shows how to calculate the shares of specific nationalities:

Thus, if your candidate belongs to Nationality A, your firm’s share of PMETs from nationality A would be:

30 (Nationality A PMETs) / 100 (Total PMETs) = 30%

questionListItems.title: How does COMPASS calculate my organisation’s local PMET share relative to my organisation’s sector?

answer.body:
Under COMPASS, we will rank organisations based on their local PMET share. The higher the percentage of local PMET employees, the higher the organisation's percentile will be.

To calculate your organisation's local PMET share, take the number of local PMET employees and divide it by the total number of PMET employees.

Definition of locals

Locals refer to Singapore citizens and permanent residents who are paid CPF contributions.

Sector comparison of local PMET share

Your organisation’s local PMET share will be ranked against other organisations in the same sector to obtain its percentile. For example:

  • A organisation at the 20th percentile would have a local PMET share that is higher than 20% of organisations in the same sector.
  • A organisation at the 50th percentile would have a local PMET share that is higher than 50% of organisations in the same sector.

You can find out your organisation’s percentile by checking the Workforce Insights Tool in myMOM portal.

questionListItems.title: How do I check and update my organisation's sector classification?

answer.body:
To find out your organisation’s sector classification:

  1. Log in to myMOM Portal.
  2. Check the "Local PMETs" chart in the Workforce Insights tool.

Note: Your organisation will be grouped into the relevant sector in COMPASS based on the primary business activity declared to ACRA and other UEN issuance agencies, regardless of whether the organisation operates across multiple sectors.

Keep your organisation's business activity up-to-date

Do update ACRA with your organisation's latest Singapore Standard Industry Classification (SSIC) information when there are changes in your primary business activity.

Once you have updated your firms’ business activity with ACRA or your respective UEN issuance agency, your records will be automatically updated with MOM on a weekly basis. You would also be able to view your firms’ updated sector classification in the Workforce Insights tool.

Inaccurate or missing SSIC information may result in work pass delays or rejections.

List of industry sectors under COMPASS

Under COMPASS, we have broadly categorised SSIC codes into the following sectors: 

  • Accommodation
  • Admin & support services
  • Air & sea transport
  • Arts, entertainment & recreation
  • Banking and other financial services#
  • Construction
  • Education
  • Food & beverage services
  • Fund management services#
  • Health & social services
  • Info-communication technology
  • Insurance services#
  • Land transport & logistics
  • Manufacturing
  • Media
  • Professional services
  • Public admin & defence
  • Real estate services
  • Retail trade
  • Utilities and other goods producing industries
  • Wholesale trade
  • Other community, social & personal services

# Organisations in these financial services sector which are subjected to a higher EP Qualifying Salary in Stage 1.

questionListItems.title: How often will my organisation's COMPASS workforce profile be updated?

answer.body:
On the 6th day of every month, we will update your organisation's COMPASS profile on myMOM Portal.

The update includes:

  • Share of nationalities among PMETs in your organisation (used in C3 – Diversity).
  • Local PMETs share in your organisation (used in C4 – Support for Local Employment).
  • Number of PMET employees in your organisation (used to assess your organisation’s eligibility for small organisation default points on C3 and C4).

To reduce sudden fluctuations, we will use an average of the last 3 months of available data.

 

On the 6th of May, your organisation’s workforce profile will be updated based on the average of data in January, February, and March. Workforce data for April is not included as CPF contributions for April are collected in May, and can only be reflected on the 6th of June.
